title: At close of business on 26 January 2022, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 15 December 2021?
preds:
Heard some analysts say that they expected a hike before the end of January, "a surprise announcement0", but doubted it based on the shock that would represent to markets, yet, given what we have seen in the markets this week, would it be a surprise or a shock? Are the markets already pricing a rate hike? Nasdaq fell more than 1% in every session this past week (4 day week but this had not happened since the dot-com bubble - Bloomberg). The Nasdaq is also on course for its worst month since the 2008 financial crisis. The CBOE volatility index, cost options tied to the Nasdaq, jumped 8 points this past week as well, its lowest since last March. Selling seems consistent, can't find analysis saying whether this is the start of bottoming or "something worse". 
- Most seem to be expecting at hike by March
- The S&P also had it's worst week since March 2020, the Dow had its worst week since Oct 2020. Only the consumer staples sector closed in the green, stay-at-home stocks were also under pressure. Netflix price drop got a lot of press and was seen as a sign of a "more fundamental weakness than a lot of people expected"
-After the Fed's December meeting, most analysts had outline 3 hikes for this year, March, June, September but now many are adding a forecast of a raise in December of 2022. Could it be that they see a need to accelerate it instead and do it in January? 
Forecasts call for a benchmark of 1.00 to 1.25 by the end of 2022, with increases of .25 per quarter. The Fed’s overnight borrowing rate is currently anchored in a range between 0%-0.25%, most recently around 0.08%. Here's the CME FedWatch Tool with their latest probabilities of FOMC rate moves with the CME FedWatch Tool.
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html# - The Fed is meeting Tuesday and Wednesday of next week (Jan 25 and 26); does it count if any announcement is made on the 26 before close of business?
The money and bond markets have already discounted a move of over 25 basis points, which opens a window for early move by Fed.
Not going to change until March meeting too shocking to the system.

Today, minutes of the Federal Reserve’s December meeting were made public and they showed officials considered raising interest rates earlier and faster than previously expected. Yields on U.S. 10-year notes rose as much as six basis points to 1.71%, the highest since April, while overnight swaps markets started pricing in an 80% chance of a 25 basis-point rate hike at the Fed’s March policy meeting. (Bloomberg). US stocks closed down sharply following the news.

Minutes from Dec meeting indicate a slight impatience on Fed's part to increase the rate- however it seems overwhelmingly likely that the earliest point - they would consider raising interest rates would be from March. Means status quo for Jan 22.
time frame is too short for any changes
https://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/opolicy/operating_policy_211215 Tapering doesn't even begin until mid January. I would be very surprised if they went ahead with an interest rate hike so soon.
But not much higher. The Fed are looking to curb inflation and so will have to nudge up interest rates to help.
They're tapering through March, so it seems very unlikely they raise rates before the taper completes. +2 to same
The Fed is still reducing it's bond market purchases, there will be some time before it starts to direclty increase rates
a rate hike next month would mark an extremely dramatic shift in policy given the conversation is currently around accelerating taper
The Fed has proven itself to be slow to act.
The Fed must raise rates.  But it will act slowly at first.
Going up 3 on higher as another inflation month like October has a chance of happening and could cause the FED to act fast.

As the central bank prepares to remove emergency stimulus measures to support the economy, sustained inflation could force the Fed to move faster than it would like, before the labor market is fully healed. In newly released minutes from their latest policymaking meeting, Fed officials appear split, with “various” members arguing that interest rates should stay near zero for a couple of yearst, while “a number” said that rates would need to go up next year, with inflation most “likely to remain elevated in 2022 with risks to the upside.” A recent Fed survey suggests that consumer expectations for inflation are running at historic high. Dealbook NYT newsletter by Ross Sorkin
Will be the same as Fed will be in the middle of bond purchase tapering (at best)
Liftoff will not begin until the end of Taper. Taper will end middle of 2022. Fed funds rate will stay the same until the middle of 2022.

The Fed has held these limits for a long time
The pressure to change them is weak

The Fed's dot plot from the September meeting imply a central tendency of one hike in 2022, and Chair Powell has implied that tapering would need to end before hikes start.  Further, the bar for rate hikes remains high per Chair Powell's most recent press conference.  It is expected that tapering to end in mid-2022, even though it has not been announced tapering will start.  Many market participants took the statement of "soon" to imply that tapering would be announced in November and start in December 2021. The reason the Fed would hike earlier than expected would be focused around inflation materially surprising to the upside AND looking like it will continue to increase in early 2021.  Effectively, there would need to be a shift away from "transitory" inflation to a permanently higher inflation well above 2% for core PCE.  Given the time horizon of the forecasting window this shift would be dramatic shift in the economy.   Sources: 
- https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/monetary20210922a1.pdf
- https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/fomcprojtabl20210922.pdf
- https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcpresconf20210922.htm

+ Inflation will rise more than expected, so the Fed will raise the rate ( cheap price product from China will diminish, higher price for transportation, higher price for energy)
- Covid -19 will still effect the world economy so the G-7 will try to stimulate it
- High government debt need low rate
- High government debt need devaluation of money

The next move will be lower to negative, not to raise rates. They will reduce quantitative easing a little bit, then the market will crash, then they will increase quantitative easing. They will never raise rates.

I find it a near 0 possibility they would go to negative rates.  The most likely outcome is that it will remain the same.  A rate increase is probable for 2022, but early in the year would seem a little too fast.  Even in a fast inflation environment, the Fed has stated they would accelerate taper before looking to raise rates.

The fed needs to taper its bond buying before it raises interest rates, which should take 6-8 months [1]. I would expect the FOMC to move away from 0% by mid-to-late 2022, but not before then. [1] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/fed-could-fracture-in-2022-over-when-to-raise-interest-rates-economist-says-11632244116
The rate will rise prior to the end of 2021, a quick additional rise is not likely.
